Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Natural Organic Matter and its Impact on Drinking Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
1521562 (Gonsior)

This award supports international travel and registration for the workshop "NOM 2015 - 6th IWA Specialist Workshop on Natural Organic Matter in Drinking Water" (NOM 6) for six early-career faculty, one post-doctoral scholar, and 10 students. The NOM 6 workshop is an important international meeting that brings experts together to discuss recent research efforts focused on the impact of natural organic matter (NOM) on drinking water systems and is jointly organized by the International Water Association (IWA) and the Swedish water utility Sydvatten. It will be held in September 2015 in Sweden. At this workshop, experts in NOM join with environmental engineers to foster new collaborations and to advance the scientific understanding of NOM and its impacts on drinking water treatment processes. The travel team members span a large research area of NOM and how it relates to drinking water treatment. All members of the travel team will give an oral or poster presentation. The travel team will collaborate on a review article focused on the fate and effects of NOM during drinking water treatment; that manuscript is to be submitted by March, 2016.

NOM affects drinking water treatment processes around the world, but specific regions face unique treatment challenges due to differences in source water quality and regulatory framework. The travel team represents geographically diverse regions of the United States (Northeast, Southeast, Midwest, West, and Southwest regions) that each have important differences in water resources and NOM signatures; therefore, the NOM 6 workshop will provide a means for the six faculty participants and a post-doctoral scholar to build new collaborations with each other and international participants. This workshop brings researchers, consultants, and drinking water utility representatives together and allows for exposure to different NOM challenges and solutions from around the world. Knowledge transfer between biogeochemists and environmental engineers is crucial to advance understanding of NOM and its complexity with water treatment processes, so that emerging drinking water treatment challenges are approached with full utilization of contemporary analytical tools and fundamental understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International water Association NOM 6 Specialty Workshop was an important international meeting that brought experts together to discuss recent research efforts in drinking water treatments with a specific focus on how disinfection by-products are formed. These unwanted by-products during disinfection of drinking water pose a health risk to consumers and scientific reserach is needed to minimize them. The meeting was jointly organized by the International Water Association (IWA) and the Swedish water utility Sydvatten. Natural scientists must join with environmental engineers to foster new collaborations and to advance the scientific understanding of disinfection by-product formation and its impacts on drinking water treatment processes. The 15 travel team members span a large research area and consisted of 6 early carrier assistant professors and 9 students. Members of the travel team gave oral or poster presentations, including a keynote lecture presented by PI Gonsior. All participants described the workshop as an oustanding opportunities to network, and to create new collaborations to advance our understanding of the formation of disinfection by products that pose a thread to human health.

PI Michael Gonsior and William Cooper presented jointly a keynote with the title "A Retrospective of Natural Organic Matter Research for Water Applications". PI Gonsior also presented a talk with the title "Dissolved Organic Matter Molecular Composition Changes during Drinking Water Production-A Case Study of a Swedish Drinking Water Treatment Plant". PI Blaney’s student Mangalgiri presented a talk with the title "Role of dissolved organic matter on UV transformation of antibiotics in agriculture-impacted water supplies". PI Alex Chow presented a talk with the title "Impacts of Wildfire on Dissolved Organic Matter and Disinfection Byproduct Precursors in Forested Watersheds". PI Korak presented a talk with the title "Fluorescence monitoring for DOM removal by coagulation: the relative (un)importance of wavelength selection". PI Shah presented a talk with the title "Formation of Disinfection By-products during Ballast Water Treatment with Chlorine, Ozone, and Peracetic Acid: Influence of Water Quality Parameters". PI Liu's student Lucy Li presented a talk with the title "Blending Desalinated Water into the Drinking Water Distribution System: Effects of NOM on Iron Corrosion and Iron Release". In addition to the oral presentations, posters were presented by PI Blaney (Title: "Characterizing effects of advanced oxidation on dissolved organic matter in agriculturally-­impacted surface water using PARAFAC"); PI Keen (title: "Characterization of organic matter in landfill leachate for treatment process optimization"); PI Keen's student Nicole Kennedy Neth (title: "Impact of organic matter on transformation products of doxycycline during water disinfection with chlorine"); PI Chow's student Rogers (title: "Effects of Prescribed Fire on Dissolved Organic Matter in Coastal Plain Forested Watersheds"); and PI Blaney's student Rogers (title: "Using EEM Analysis to Identify and Characterize the Impacts of Leaking Wastewater Infrastructure on Urban Water Resources").
